utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Let's stay focused, Johnny. What are you looking at?

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: Who is she?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: That's Miss Cindy, Zeke's new aide.

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: What happened to his old aide?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: She got married. So, first, you want to rub the glue on the paper in any shapes you like.

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: Why do people get married?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Because they love each other.

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: Why aren't you married?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I haven't found the person I love yet, because I spend all of my time loving you.

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: Does that mean we can get married?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Well, love comes in many types, and there's lots of it to go around.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Oh, my snow is ruined.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: It's not ruined. Oh, it's pretty. See, look, I like the green.

utterance.speaker: Jessica
utterance.content: Who ever heard of green snow?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: It's magical. Come here. We'll get you cleaned up, okay? It's okay. Ooh, are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You gonna pay for that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nice of you to offer. Now I can actually get some cream cheese.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 29-year-old teacher. She works with special needs children. She —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Love what you're wearing. Brings out the blue of the case file, which means it's not from the ER. So why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because Dr. Cuddy is not here. She's decided to spend some more time at home with the baby for a while. I'm taking over some of her day-to-day responsibilities, like babysitting you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Interesting. You have your whole life ahead of you. So why would Cuddy want you to die so young?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She figured I'd spent three years working for you. I was inoculated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good. Fun. You get to exercise your newfound power. I squirm under your thumb, resent the student becoming the teacher, and then push comes to shove, and we all get to realize what our real roles should be. Then you put out.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That's why I took the job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 29-year-old Special Ed Teacher coughs up blood all over Corky. No dyspnea, no weight loss. Why are you smirking?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Never thought I'd see the day you were taking orders from Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cameron's in charge?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: When did that happen?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You're gonna destroy her, aren't you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am going to do my job. If that involves leaving her a rotting pulp…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cameron’s gonna mark her territory. She'll probably over compensate and destroy you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Bleeding ulcer.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Scope of the stomach and lungs were clean, yet she continues to spit up blood from both her stomach and lungs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That means it's probably something wrong with the blood itself — Leukemia, Von Willebrand's.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Thoracic tumor is a better fit. Erodes into her airway and esophagus —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, will you two stop it already?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Stop what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Disagreeing.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Okay, which one of us shouldn't have an opinion?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's not an opinion. It's a smoke screen. Toss out a lame idea, instead of agreeing with Foreman's better idea because you're worried that'll confirm that he's boldly gone where no man has gone before.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You slept with Foreman?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sorry. You were busy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Drop it, House. We're seeing each other, end of discussion. Anything else isn't relevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's extremely relevant. Apparently, it colors everything. Now I have no idea if you have differing opinions because you have differing opinions or because you're just trying to prove that you can think for yourselves.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: How about you just judge our ideas on their own merit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, you don't want me to do that. Go run a bleeding-time test, confirm our patient's blood is screwy, then you can come back and pretend to disagree about why.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Time zero.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I'm impressed. You didn't even flinch.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I just went to my happy place.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We cannot let House anywhere near this woman.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Where is your happy place?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: My class. With them.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Passed the first mark.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's a great thing you do.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Not really. Most kids, typical children, you hand them a pair of scissors, and they cut. Well, Tony, he's got CP and when I gave him the scissors, we went on a journey together, learning to get his fingers in those holes, to hold the scissors apart, to hold the paper. I mean, when he finally learned to cut, we both just wept with joy.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If you ever meet our boss, just yes or no answers, okay?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It's not slowing up. No sign of clotting.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: So there is something wrong with my blood?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Don't worry, we'll run some lab tests to find out which clotting factor is off and then —

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I'm not worried.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Must be one hell of a happy place.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She's beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know. I'm lucky.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Absolutely. What's she like?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She's eight weeks old. Are you asking me about her politics or her sense of humor?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My cousin had a kid. They acted like they knew the thing from the time it was two minutes old. I just… I just thought…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She cries, she eats, and she poops.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't feel anything.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're tired.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm not sleep deprived. She sleeps fine. I'm obviously not hormonal. I know I'm supposed to feel amazement. I'm supposed to love her. I just… I don't feel anything at all. Sorry. Maybe I am just tired. Um. Thank you for stopping by. I'm okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Lisa… if you're…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am feeding her, I'm changing her, and I'm burping her. I'm doing everything I'm supposed to do. She will be okay. Please go back to work.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It is the blood, but the clotting proteins aren't the problem.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's her platelets, looked like they had bite marks in them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So now you're agreeing? Either you folded because I gave you crap, or you broke up, or —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We disagree, you blame our relationship. We agree, you blame our relationship. Don't you see a problem there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. Don't you?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Could be lymphoma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not with normal LDH.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: ITP fits. We should start her on methotrexate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely, and total body irradiation.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Because she failed a bleeding-time test?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: TBI will promote cancers, kill her digestive tract.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't forget, stop her from bleeding into her brain.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's premature, reckless, and potentially lethal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True. Must be somebody's job to stop me from being reckless and irresponsible. Nobody can stop me from being premature.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got a patient with ITP. Need to hit her with radiation.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm gonna have to call you back. Methotrexate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good point. On the other hand, if she bleeds in her brain, she's gonna need a Special Ed class of her own.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, if you think it's right, do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmmm. Some people thought you were gonna be brutal, marking your territory.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Who?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nobody. Just because I call him nobody doesn't make me a racist.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm not gonna play games. If you come to me with a request and it makes medical sense, I’ll say yes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need oral sex. I'm pretty sure biological imperative qualifies as medical sense.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can I return my phone call now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't really see how that's gonna be possible.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Patient won't respond to methotrexate. Bleeding time hasn't improved.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a medical dilemma for me. I have one for you. I need a reason to not do total body irradiation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Other than that Cameron said you can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She said I can.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Then why don't we just do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because it's premature, reckless, and potentially lethal.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Then why don't we just don't do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because that would let Cameron in on the fact that I never intended to do it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is gonna be convoluted, isn't it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I figured I'd ask for something really crazy, so she'd shoot me down and get the whole "I can control House" thing out of her perky little system. So the next time I went back and asked for something marginally crazy, it would seem marginally reasonable, and she'd say yes. So, yeah, slightly convoluted.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You're screwed.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Unless we irradiate her. Without the radiation. We book the nuclear lab. We fill out the paperwork. We bring the patient down there. We do everything but flip the switch.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go. Do. Don't flip.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And is there anything we should be doing, you know, to actually help the patient?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trust me. In the long term, this'll help all our patients. In the short term, double the dose of methotrexate and add prednisone.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Cameron's got the keys to the castle.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This trial I'm running — the drug really seems to be working.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's kind of liking the power. I think I'm kind of liking her liking it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm not sure what I'm gonna do about Thirteen.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She's sort of dressing like Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's on the placebo.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can't possibly know that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Accidents happen. I found out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You cannot tell her. You'd be compromising the trial. She knows she had a 50/50 chance of not being on the drug. If you feel like you're lying to her, too bad.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't want to tell her. I want to put her on the real drug.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And you want me to tell you that that's okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her trial results are already compromised, just from the fact that I know. As long as she's wasting her time, why not give her something that might actually help her?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Valid point, except for the fact that it's a load of crap. Don't be an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: So how long until we start the procedure?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We already started. Told you you wouldn't feel a thing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You should lie back. Just stay real still.

utterance.speaker: Pan Am Clerk
utterance.content: I'm afraid there is someone sitting next to you.

utterance.speaker: Fletch
utterance.content: Oh, for — God, God, God!

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I have to pee. Can we, like, call a time out for a minute, let me go to the bathroom?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yeah, sure. We'll just start up again when you're done.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Thanks. Sorry. I… I didn't realize I had to go.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No problem.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sarah?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No pulse. Get the paddles.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Clear!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Got a pulse. It's not ITP. She clearly doesn't need fake radiation.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No structural defects in her heart.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What about a calcified valve or a patent foramen ovale?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Transthoracic echo and bubble studies show nothing. Her heart's clean.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The patient said she had to go pee. Maybe when she got up, she started to urinate. Increased the vagal tone, caused arrhythmia, and stopped her heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who has to go pee in the middle of a nuclear procedure?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It wasn't really a nuclear procedure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She didn't know that. People don't die from peeing.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Heavy metal, toxin.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Drugs or alcohol.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Or her own body is making a toxin. Cold agglutinins. Abnormal protein gets activated by cold temperatures.

utterance.speaker: Forbes
utterance.content: Like the classroom with the broken heater and the cold metal table in the procedure room.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, for God's sake, get a room. Immerse her in an ice bath. The cold will activate her cold agglutinins.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Causing her heart to race.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Confirming our diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: And giving her another heart attack.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lucky for me, there's a flaxen-haired maiden who loves to say yes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How in the world could you approve total body irradiation for a patient with possible ITP?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It was the right call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There is no medical justification for that kind of —

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not medically, no. Absolutely no medical rationalization. I had to say yes because House wanted me to say no.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You think he was bluffing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm the new kid. He had to test me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Don't get cute. Don't engage him. Do not play his games, because you will lose.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You hired me to do this job. Let me do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I'm sorry. Looks like you guys are in the middle of a conversation. I can wait till Cuddy leaves. You are gonna leave soon, aren't you? I mean, the nurses have got your baby out there. Not that they're gonna kidnap it or anything, but I figured that the new mother brings the baby to work because she wants to listen to all the cooing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If you're gonna wait, you can wait outside.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless the new mother brings the baby to work because she wants to dump the baby, because she hates the baby and thinks she made a big mistake. You can't trust that Wilson guy with anything.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Lisa, are you —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's not a big deal. I was having a bad day.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is Wilson gonna be in trouble?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: For betraying my trust in a vulnerable time? No. Why would that bother me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He was worried, made a bad choice. It's not a big deal. I know it seems like crap, you probably feel like crap, but it's not. Legally, you haven't adopted her yet. There's no obligations, no strings. It can be undone tomorrow. Emotionally, you'll feel guilty for a while, but the kid… She won't even know you existed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You saying I should give her back?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Much better than having a mother who doesn't give a crap.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thanks. I'm just gonna go drop it off at the pound.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What did you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We got a green light. Go draw the patient's blood.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To see if it clumps in the cold.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: She's making you confirm your theory before you treat?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She approved the bath. Just thought we ought to do a test to confirm.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That's more of a yellow light, isn't it?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So she lets you nuke the patient, no problem, but makes you jump through hoops to give her a bath? Why would she do that?

utterance.speaker: Forman
utterance.content: I think she was playing you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go draw the blood.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Didn't realize the nurses allowed any visitors in here.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: They don't. We'll just do these problems, and then you have to go, okay?

utterance.speaker: Johnny
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I need to draw some blood. I had a crush on my teacher in fourth grade… and fifth.

utterance.speaker: Tammy
utterance.content: It's more that Johnny was a nonverbal autistic. Then for Sarah, he talks, makes eye contact. He's like a regular kid. Since she got sick, he started going back away from us. I had to bring him in for a visit.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I'll tell you what, I'll close the blinds so the nurses don't ask questions. You can stay as long as you want. We should have the results in about an hour.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I'll be here. Good job.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: One minute at 39 degrees.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Oh, damn, sorry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You all right?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Don't be paranoid. I feel great. Didn't expect the meds to work this quickly.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Let's not get ahead of ourselves. You might not even be on the real drug.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Several patients have shown improvement. I know my test results have been better. I know I have more energy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You ever hear the term placebo effect?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I guess I do have a few reasons to feel good. But let's not get ahead of ourselves. You're good, but not "curing Huntington’s" good.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It's clumped. House was right. Ice bath's on.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Got a sec?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don't be an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I know it's hard, but you need to stay in there for three minutes.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: It's okay.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You come to procedures now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only the ones that might involve stopping the patient's heart.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Cameron tell you to be here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Tell me about Jonathan. How'd you get him to come out of hiding?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: He was extremely sensitive to touch, yet he had a… a tactile fascination with newspaper. I mean, he wouldn't read it. He would just… just touch it, crinkle it. I thought maybe that was a way in. Papier mâché and… and it was. He let me into his world.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Please tell her that talking will ruin the test.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: All the kids — I try to become a part of them, and then have them become a part of me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How much longer till the heart attack?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I wanted to be a doctor from the time I was eight years old. Never wanted to be a pediatrician, though.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now they're both talking.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Well, I wanted to be a sociologist. I was supposed to observe a class. I was sent to room 214, but I went to room 241 instead. It was a Special Ed class, and I just… I just felt at home.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Time. Heart rate's normal.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You can get out now.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It's not cold agglutinins.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm not surprised. She obviously has brain damage. Seriously.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She screwed up a room number six years ago, and you decide she has brain damage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Transposed digits. Classic marker for number confusion. Means she has a lesion in her left parahippocampal region.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I misdialed a phone number this morning. Must be contagious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She also forgot to pee before your fake test.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So she has a small bladder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shows an inability to predict the future.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Also located in the left hemisphere of the brain, close to the parahippocampal region.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Means the damage is ongoing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Two subtle clues, six years apart. That's hardly compelling evidence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm compelled.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That's not what this is. Every time a decent person comes in, you set out to prove that they have brain damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I never said her deranged personality was a symptom.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don't need to. I've been here five years. I can hear your thoughts from my apartment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can you hear me now?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Move onto another organ.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The screwed up numbers and forgetting to pee points to her being a human being. The platelet dysfunction and cardiac arrest points to a pancreatic tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or multiple sclerosis. The brain is like the Internet, packets of information constantly flowing from one area to another. Plaques in her brain are like a bad server, slow down the flow. If it's in the parahippocampus, it'll spread to the brain stem, which means it'll be the lungs next. Brain biopsy will show you the plaques.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Or we could not cut into her brain. It's just her pancreas. We should do an ERCP.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, we could settle this with rock, paper, scissors, but, unfortunately, there are people who adjudicate these disputes.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: A pancreatic tumor is much more likely to kill her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not this week, not next week, not next month.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The number confusions six years ago. You don't think we have time for an ERCP?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The heart attack was six hours ago. Now, maybe it's planning to go into hiding for a couple years, or maybe it's gonna hit her lungs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Stop! We have to assume it's the brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'll go fire up the biopsy drill.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, we had to assume it's the brain until we prove otherwise. Do an MRI, T-2 images.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want me to do another test?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You should be able to see the MS plaques. If they exist, you can do your biopsy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. You wanna say yes. You know you should say yes. But you also think that this job is about standing up to me. So you're not gonna say yes. You're not gonna say no. You're just gonna waste time. And the patient's brain, or pancreas, or whatever is wrong with her is not gonna wait for you to impress your boss. So pick one, either him or me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do the MRI.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You still here? The whole point of giving Cameron the job was so that you could —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't wanna go home. House told me I should give her back. Instead of being offended, I've been wondering if he's right.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He's not. He never is, not when it's anything personal, or human, or…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, he's always cold. He's always an ass, but he's very rarely just wrong. I've read every bonding and attachment book there is. I feel like I'm in prison at home. I feel like I'm free here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Parents make sacrifices.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't know if I want to. I'm not proud of this. I feel terrible. I feel like a failure. But she deserves to be loved.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I… I… I don't know what to say.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No plaques on the left hemisphere.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Or the right.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Even magnified images of her hippocampal region, nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is surprising.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So can we cancel the biopsy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go ahead with the ERCP.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I need to talk to you about Remy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thirteen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did you call her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She's on placebo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you want to change that. I'm the last person you'd ever come to for ethical advice, literally, which means you've already asked every other person, and no one's given you the answer you want.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or I respect your opinion, and I want to hear what comes to your mind.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Has she invited any of her lesbian friends into bed with you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I was mistaken.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Drug gonna cure her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It looks promising, reducing symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No cure then. So, the pros are you might delay the onset of symptoms, give her an extra year, maybe three. She's still dead before you're 45. The question is, are those few years worth risking the rest of your life in medicine?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There, that wasn't so hard, was it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're welcome. Unless you love her. If you love her, then you do stupid things.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Common bile duct is clear.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No filling defects in the biliary tree.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's her lungs. House was right. O2 sat's down to 89.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Increase to 100% O2.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Better get out.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Do we have to tell him?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The surgeons were able to drain the pleural effusions. The patient's breathing on her own, but she's still pretty weak.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lung failure proves that one of us was right. Who said “brain”?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Yes, you predicted that her lungs would fail, but the MRI was negative for MS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was right about the where, but not the what. A picornavirus could cause localized demyelination that the MRI wouldn't pick up. If we run a nerve-conduction study on the surface of her brain we'll see the dead spots.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Are you talking about cutting into her skull?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, I'm talking about cutting off her skull, exposing her brain.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: A pancreatic tumor could still fit. It explains the heart, the blood, and her lungs.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: ERCP was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And she agrees with me because she agrees with me, right, sweetie?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: All we need is a more sensitive test. Endoscopic ultrasound.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just accept that you've been proven wrong.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You were also proven wrong. Why don't I get a second test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because if I'm right about the brain, then we don't have time to indulge your wrongness.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Let me know when Cameron says yes to cutting off our patient's skull. I'll be doing the endoscopic ultrasound.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good news. I don't need your approval for some crazy, unproven treatment. I just need to do a test.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You wanna remove your patient's skull.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Remind me to revoke Kutner’s telephone privileges.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I didn't realize that was an AMA-approved treatment for MS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not searching for MS, but what set it off — equine encephalitis. Turned a cool breeze of MS into a Cat 5 storm.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I didn't realize your patient was a horse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's been human cases.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not when it's 30 degrees outside. Transmission is by mosquito.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So she got bitten six months ago, or it's some other infection. Whatever it is, it's running rampant in the left side of her brain. When I get in there, I’ll get you the specifics.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're asking me to let you cut off the top of someone's head. I need more than, "I'll know it when I see it."

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you want proof before you let me go looking for the proof? This is the test.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You have to give me something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy's gonna love you. The patient, on the other hand, is gonna hate you until the day she dies next week. Actually, this idiot will probably forgive you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You gonna help or what?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I want kids.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Um, I think these kids are already spoken for.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not now. But since we're dating, I just thought you should know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But I thought, because of your illness —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: So did I. Even when I didn't know if I had it or not, I just assumed I couldn't take the chance, but now… Even though I know I have it, it feels like… an option.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You really don't have to keep buying me things.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Just open it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This is nice.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The picture is actually your gift. That's your baby. I took her picture to one of those places that does that age-enhancement thing. And according to the kid who works there, this is a pretty good approximation of what your daughter will look like 18 years from now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's, uh, sort of cool.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Right now she's just this weird little creature that sleeps and poops and cries. But that… is who she's gonna be. You will be teaching her how to ride a bike, giving her advice about friends and school and having her heart broken. She'll ignore most of it, but some of it'll stick. You're gonna be there for her through all of that. You just have to get through this part. That's all.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's very sweet. I'll pay you back for the photo.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Don't worry about it. It's just the picture that came with the frame. You can chuck it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kid with a raging viral syndrome and three dead mosquitoes. I'm off to storm the Bastille.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: These aren't mosquitoes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fruit flies. Close enough.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Acute viral nasopharyngitis? One of her students has the common cold?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Team's not what it used to be. On the other hand, Kutner ran his endoscopic ultrasound, didn't find peep.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So disproving it's her pancreas proves it's her brain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. You used to do this job, remember? That's what used to pass for evidence.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Now I do this job. You brought me three dead bugs and a runny nose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can't find you the proof you want because it's trapped inside her head. And the only way I can get at it is to cut it open and rip it out, which is apparently the one test you won't let me run. So either I do this, or I do nothing.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What do you want me to do? Say yes just because you're House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'd certainly like that, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cameron actually said yes?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, I'm just obsessive about clean cuticles.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Sawing off the top of her skull and placing electrodes on her brain is insane.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, we should be retesting her pancreas for the umpteenth time.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You're skipping steps because it's Cameron. You haven't figured her out yet, and you want to see how far you can push.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm skipping steps because our patient is skipping steps on the way to being dead. If you've got a better idea…

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We should remove her spleen. Splenic lymphoma explains the damaged platelets, the heart, the lungs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If this doesn't work, the spleen's all yours. Unless I kill her, of course.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not only will this allow us to clock your brain's processing speed, you'll also get free cable for the first three months. What's this?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: A blue car. Is that part of the test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, my lease is up next month. You like? I'm gonna ask you a series of questions designed to stimulate left-brain function — logic, reasoning, problem-solving. Or as my mentor, Old Ben, liked to call it, "The dark side." If we find slow areas, we know we found damage. We treat. You go home. Ready?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: I'd nod yes, but I can't move my head.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This pen is red. Its ink is red. Is all ink red?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nerve conduction's 12. 8 meters per second. Right within range.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Cameron's letting him cut into our patient's skull based on nothing but dead bugs and someone else's runny nose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There are two pints in a quart, four quarts in a gallon. How many pints in five gallons?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, step away from the patient.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Who's that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay, all right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's my old boss. And by "old," I don't mean "former."

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Insulting me is not gonna make me go away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're not here. Obviously I'm not trying to make you go away. Hint — the answer is a number.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 12.4 meters per second. Conduction is still normal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron, you're actually assisting him with this?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yes, because I'm actually familiar with this case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, I'm familiar enough to know that cutting into this woman's brain is not necessary.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Is she serious?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, she's certainly not funny. Put the phone down. Pick up the baby. Make us all happy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay, settle down, baby. It's okay. We'll be done in a minute. House, I can call security. I can —

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: BP's dropping.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get it back up. I got a whole stack of these.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Give her ten CCs dopamine.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Already am, thanks. Your baby needs you a lot more than we do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You aren't hungry, and you aren't wet. I don't know what it is.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Oh, that is so annoying. Can you make it stop?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Baby's crying is annoying you? What's her nerve conduction?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 14.3. It's actually speeding up. But her BP's 80 over palp. We're gonna have to stop.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That doesn't make any sense.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The fact that you're wrong doesn't make any sense, or the fact that believed that you were right? BP's still dropping. She's gonna stroke. I'm giving her ten more CCs, and I'm putting an end to this.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay, Rachel, quiet down! I need you to be quiet!

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Please, turn that phone off!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why does the baby annoy you, but no one else does? I mean, you're right about her, but —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I don't know what you want! I will give you anything that you want! I don't know what it is! Tell me! Please, just help me! Please! Really? That worked?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She's stable. We're finished here. Close her up.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: How long until we can perform the splenectomy?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can't dose her with anesthesia till the last batch completely clears.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How come the baby annoyed her?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We should get her in there as soon as we can.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Two hours at least.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Her blood pressure's in the tank. I hope she lasts two hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What was different? Our patient loves all things annoying.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She'd love this conversation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's an earth mother, takes in the freaks and rejects of humanity and tells them they're a-okay. So what was different?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Her head was open, you were asking her questions, a baby was crying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She had low blood pressure. According to the laws of physics, low blood pressure causes light-headedness, chest pain, but not annoyance.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Move your feet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You decided to keep her. Thank you for telling me. You can go now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I talked to her. We connected.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You talked at her. You had a chemical reaction.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are you trying to annoy me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm trying to explain you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know it doesn't make any sense, but it was real. It was there. You want to hold her? Come here. Come say hi.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think we'll bond?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is that cute?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A little.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I threw up on you, you'd be pissed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your puke isn't as cute.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's 'cause of your hips. If she would've just gestated a little longer, her stomach sphincter would be fully mature. But, no, we have to walk upright, which means that baby's head is too big for mommy's hips. And by the way, your hips may be an evolutionary improvement. So we've evolved to find baby puke cute, 'cause otherwise we'd kill them all before they became functional. Bonding's over. I got to go see another baby.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: So I can just live spleen-free?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Plenty of people live perfectly normal lives without —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spleen's fine.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's not her brain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course it's her brain.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You looked at her brain. You took off her skull. You found nothing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn't look in the right part. Didn't look in the heart part. In the womb, blood has to bypass the lungs, since they don't work yet. When we're born, we take our first big breath, lungs expand, and the ductus closes. Yours didn't.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: She has a patent ductus arteriosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When you get stressed, your blood pressure goes up and forces open the ductus. Blood takes a little detour, makes it leak from your nose, your stomach, your lungs, and, more significantly, keeps it flowing to the right side of your brain and away from your left. Which means that when you get stressed, you get unstressed. That's why you're so good with those annoying kids. And why, when your blood pressure dropped, you were able to identify Cuddy as an annoying human being. Good news is we can fix the heart. Bad news for the annoying kids.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She's incredible.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Thank you. Great work today. I should've trusted your instincts. I will in the future.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I quit.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I think I just apologized. If you want, I can get down on my knees.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's not because of you. I approved an insane procedure with no proof, no evidence, no —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You made the right call. The problem was a brain problem. Without the procedure, House never notices the increased left-brain function. She'd be dead if you hadn't said yes.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know. But… I'll always say yes to House. I studied under him. He's in my head. And if you gave anyone else this job, they would always say no, because… well, because they should. House is insane.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Which leaves me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Hey, buddy! It's okay, buddy. Come here. Oh, I missed you so much. I missed you.
